lexUnit.name: flutter.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: (usu for a straight, long body part) to move with a light irregular motion

sentence.text: He was doing his winsome act , almost fluttering his eyelashes at her .
` Well , I could make it werf yer while , " she said fluttering her eyelashes at him .
She finished , fluttered her lashes at me and smoothed the corduroy dress over her wide hips .
The barmaid fluttered exotic eyelashes at the tall boy .
Jonathan fluttered his hands in the air .
For the lady -- accompanied by red admirals , peacocks and common blues -- was fluttering her wings in the new butterfly centre .
A man appeared at the end of the street , shouting and fluttering his white arms : his robe billowed like a sheet on a washing line .
Frederick was dancing round Mister Johnny , twisting one side of his face in grotesque imitation and fluttering his hands .
Jules fluttered his long , dark lashes .
` Tomorrow the galahs descend , and squawk , and flutter their plumage . "
Flora raised her eyebrows , fluttered her eyelashes and said , ` True , " pursing her lips .
He fluttered his fingers as if he 'd picked up something hot .
The tall Finn and Peter Horbury together raised her up and in a moment or two her eyelids fluttered open .
Mada Joyce bent ponderously to feel Hyacinth 's brow and the child 's eyes fluttered open .
The fat man fluttered chubby , ringed fingers .
Emily 's hand fluttered helplessly to her face , fingering her lips .
Alexandra 's hands fluttered immediately between her head and her waist .
